quest_title: If \(x ^ { m } y ^ { n } = ( x + y ) ^ { m + n } \text { then } \left. \cfrac { d y } { d x } \right| _ { x = 1 , y = 2 }\) is equal to
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { x ^ { m } y ^ { n } = ( x + y ) ^ { m + n } } \\ { x ^ { m } \cdot \left( n y ^ { n - 1 } \right) \cdot \cfrac { d y } { d x } + y ^ { n } \left( m x ^ { m - 1 } \right) = ( m + n ) ( x + y ) ^ { m + n - 1 } \left( 1 + \cfrac { d y } { d x } \right) } \\ { \text { After solving, we find } \cfrac { d y } { d x } = \cfrac { y } { x } \text { and } \left. \cfrac { d y } { d x } \right| _ { x = 1 , y = 2 } = \cfrac { 2 } { 1 } = 2 } \end{array}\)

quest_title: Two coherent sources of light can be obtained by
ans2_txt: Two different lamps but of the same power
ans3_txt: Two different lamps of same power and having the same colour
explanation_txt:
Two sources to be coherent, they should produce light of same frequency, intensity and of same phase.

It is impractical to make two independent source producing light having same phase.

explanation_plain_text:

quest_title: A flexible steel cable of length L and mass per unit length m hangs vertically from a support at one end. The time taken by transverse pulse to travel down the whole cable is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{v}=\sqrt{\cfrac{(l-\mathrm{x}) \mathrm{mg}}{\mathrm{m}}}=\sqrt{(\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{x}) \mathrm{g}}\)

or, \(\cfrac{\mathrm{dx}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\sqrt{(\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{x}) \mathrm{g}}\)

or, \(\mathrm{dt}=\cfrac{\mathrm{dx}}{\sqrt{(\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{x}) \mathrm{g}}}\)

or, \(\displaystyle{\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{dt}=\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{\mathrm{g}}} \int_{0}^{L}(\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{x})^{-1 / 2} \times \mathrm{d} \mathrm{x}}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{t}=2 \sqrt{\cfrac{\mathrm{L}}{\mathrm{g}}}\)

explanation_plain_text:

quest_title: In the circuit of figure, the final voltage drop across the capacitor \({C}\) is
explanation_txt:
In steady state, the capacitor arm presents an infinite resistance. So the potential difference across \(C\) is that across \(r_{2}\).

Current through \(r_{2}=\cfrac{V}{r_{1}+r_{2}}\)

PD across \(r_{2}=V \times \cfrac{r_{2}}{r_{1}+r_{2}}\)

quest_title: An electron of mass 0.90 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-30}\) kg under the action of magnetic field moves in a circle of radius 200 cm at a speed of 3 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-6}\) m/s. If a proton of mass 1.8 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-27}\) kg were to move in a circle of same radius in the same magnetic field, then its speed will be
explanation_txt:
\(\text { We know that, } r=\cfrac{m v}{q B} \)
Given that
\(r_{p}=r_{e}\)
\(\cfrac{m_{p} v_{p}}{e B}=\cfrac{m_{e} v_{e}}{e B} \Rightarrow v_{p}=\left(\cfrac{m_{e}}{m_{p}}\right) \times v_{e} \)
\(v_{p}=\cfrac{0.91 \times 10^{-30}}{1.6 \times 10^{-27}} \times 3 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{sec} \)
\(v_{p}=1.6 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{sec} \)
question_plain_title: An electron of mass 0.90 10 kg under the action of magnetic field moves in a circle of radius 200 cm at a speed of 3 10 m/s. If a proton of mass 1.8 10 kg were to move in a circle of same radius in the same magnetic field, then its speed will be
explanation_plain_text: Given that
ans1_plain_text: 3 10 m/sec
ans2_plain_text: 1.5 10 m/sec
ans3_plain_text: 1.5 10 m/sec

quest_title: Which of the following has the largest dipole moment?
explanation_txt:
Dipole moment = partial charge (e) x distance (d)

The dipole moment of R-Cl is more than that of R-F because of higher electronegativity of Fluorine. Although the partial charge is more in R-F, the distance is so less that the dipole moment becomes less than that of R-Cl.

In case of R-Br and R-I, despite having higher distance, the partial charge is very less, which results in lower dipole moments.
question_plain_title: Which of the following has the largest dipole moment?
explanation_plain_text:

In case of R-Br and R-I, despite having higher distance, the partial charge is very less, which results in lower dipole moments.

quest_title: For rational coefficients \(a,b,c\) the quadratic equation \(ax^2 -bx - c = 0\) has distict rational roots iff:
explanation_txt:
The discriminant of \(ax^2 -bx - c = 0\) is \(b^2 + 4ac \).

Thus the roots are rational and distinct iff \( b^2 + 4ac >0 \) and is perfect square.

quest_title: If \(a_m\) denotes the \(m^{th}\) term of an A.P. then \(a_m = \)
explanation_txt:
\(a_{m+k} =A+(m+k-1)\, D\)

and

\(a_{m-k} =A+(m-k-1)\, D\)

Adding both equations, we get;

\[\cfrac{a_{m+k} +a_{m-k} }{2} =A+(m-1)\, D=a_{m} .\]

[\(a_m\) is mean of \(a_{m+k} \) and \(a_{m-k}\)]

explanation_txt: Since \(\alpha =\beta =\gamma \, \, \, \Rightarrow \, \, \cos ^{2} \alpha +\cos ^{2} \alpha +\cos ^{2} \alpha =1\) \[\Rightarrow \, \, \alpha =\cos ^{-1} \left(\pm \, \cfrac{1}{\sqrt{3} } \right)\] So, there are four lines whose direction cosines are \[\left(\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{3} } ,\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{3} } ,\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{3} } \right),\, \left(\cfrac{-1}{\sqrt{3} } ,\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{3} } ,\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{3} } \right),\, \left(\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{3} } ,\cfrac{-1}{\sqrt{3} } ,\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{3} } \right),\left(\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{3} } ,\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{3} } ,\cfrac{-1}{\sqrt{3} } \right).\]

quest_title: \[\lim _ { x \rightarrow 0 } \cfrac { \tan x - \sin x } { x ^ { 3 } } =\]
explanation_txt: \[ \lim _ { x \rightarrow 0 } \cfrac { \tan x - \sin x } { x ^ { 3 } } = \lim _ { x \rightarrow 0 } \cfrac { \sin x - \sin x \cos x } { x ^ { 3 } \cos x } \\ = \lim _ { x \rightarrow 0 } \cfrac { \sin x \left( 2 \sin ^ { 2 } \cfrac { x } { 2 } \right) } { x ^ { 3 } \cos x } = \lim _ { x \rightarrow 0 } \left[ \cfrac { \sin x } { x } \cdot \cfrac { 2 } { \cos x } \cdot \cfrac { \sin ^ { 2 } \cfrac { x } { 2 } } { \left( \cfrac { x } { 2 } \right) ^ { 2 } } \cdot \cfrac { 1 } { 4 } \right] = \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } \]

quest_title: \(\cfrac { d } { d x } \left( x ^ { 2 } \sin \cfrac { 1 } { x } \right) =\)
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { \cfrac { d } { d x } \left( x ^ { 2 } \sin \cfrac { 1 } { x } \right) = x ^ { 2 } \cos \left( \cfrac { 1 } { x } \right) \cfrac { d } { d x } \left( \cfrac { 1 } { x } \right) + 2 x \sin \left( \cfrac { 1 } { x } \right) } \\ { = - \cfrac { 1 } { x ^ { 2 } } \cdot x ^ { 2 } \cos \left( \cfrac { 1 } { x } \right) + 2 x \sin \left( \cfrac { 1 } { x } \right) = 2 x \sin \left( \cfrac { 1 } { x } \right) - \cos \left( \cfrac { 1 } { x } \right) } \end{array}\)

quest_title: The phenomenon of interference is shown by
explanation_txt: Interference is the inherent property of wave. It is shown by all kinds of waves.
question_plain_title: The phenomenon of interference is shown by
explanation_plain_text: Interference is the inherent property of wave. It is shown by all kinds of waves.

quest_title: In the interference pattern, energy is
explanation_txt: In interference of light the energy is transferred from the region of destructive interference to the region of constructive interference. The average energy being always equal to the sum of the energies of the interfering waves. Thus, the phenomenon of interference is in complete agreement with the law of conservation of energy.
question_plain_title: In the interference pattern, energy is
explanation_plain_text: In interference of light the energy is transferred from the region of destructive interference to the region of constructive interference. The average energy being always equal to the sum of the energies of the interfering waves. Thus, the phenomenon of interference is in complete agreement with the law of conservation of energy.

quest_title: In a junction diode, the holes are due to
explanation_txt: When an electron is missing in a covalent bond, it is equivalent having a positive charge of magnitude same as that of electron in the region around the bond called hole. Thus, holes are due to absense of electrons.

quest_title: For total internal reflection to take place, the angle of incidence i and the refractive index \(\mu \) of the medium must satisfy the inequality
explanation_txt: For total internal reflection i > C \[\Rightarrow \sin i>\sin C\Rightarrow \sin i>\cfrac{1}{\mu } \Rightarrow \cfrac{1}{\sin i} <\mu .\]

quest_title: The maximum height reached by a projectile is 4 m and horizontal range is 12 m. The velocity of projection is
explanation_txt:
\(H=\cfrac{u^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta}{2 g} \)
\(\therefore u \sin \theta=\sqrt{2 g H}=\sqrt{2 g \times 4}=\sqrt{8 g} ..........(i) \)
\(R=\cfrac{u^{2} \sin 2 \theta}{g} \)

\(\text { Or, } 12=\cfrac{2 u^{2} \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta}{g}=\cfrac{2}{g}(u \sin \theta)(u \cos \theta)\)

\(\therefore u \cos \theta=\cfrac{12 g}{2 \sqrt{8 g}}=\cfrac{6 g}{\sqrt{8 g}} ...........(ii)\)

Squaring & adding (i) & (ii),

\(\begin{aligned} u &=\sqrt{8 g+\cfrac{36 g^{2}}{8 g}} \\ &=\sqrt{\cfrac{25 g}{2}}=5 \sqrt{\cfrac{g}{2}} \end{aligned}\)
